Immediately following on the WWE Network, Sting spoke for the first time in-ring.{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwerawreport/article_83884.shtml#.VQgYRo6sWPA|title=CALDWELL'S WWE RAW RESULTS 3/16: Complete "virtual-time" coverage of live Raw - Sting makes surprise appearance, U.S. Title contract signing, Lesnar speaks, more|publisher=PWTorch|date=March 16, 2015|author=Caldwell, James.}} He lost at WrestleMania 31 in a match involving interference from [[D-Generation X]] and [[New World Order (professional wrestling)|New World Order]] members, but shook hands with Triple H afterward. Sting returned on the August 24 episode of ''Raw'', interrupting [[WWE Championship|WWE World Heavyweight Champion]] [[Seth Rollins]]'s statue unveiling ceremony by attacking Rollins before challenging Rollins for the title by raising the belt over his head. Triple H then announced on the WWE Network that Sting would face Rollins for the title at [[Night of Champions (2015)|Night of Champions]]. Sting appeared on the tron throughout the September 7 ''Raw'', defacing and ultimately destroying Rollins's statue by pushing it into a garbage truck. The following week, Sting defeated [[Big Show]] by disqualification in his debut ''Raw'' match, as a consequence of Rollins attacking Sting. [[John Cena]] then came to Sting's aid, which prompted [[Triple H]] to book a tag team contest involving the four wrestlers: Sting and Cena won after Sting made Rollins tap out to the Scorpion Deathlock. Sting suffered a [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Legit|legit]] neck injury during his championship match against Rollins at [[Night of Champions (2015)|Night of Champions]], but was able to complete the bout in a losing effort.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/inside/sting-interviewed-about-night-of-champions-injuries-27958909|title=Sting on his injury, his condition and whether or not that was his last match|last=Adkins|first=Greg|date=September 23, 2015|publisher=[[WWE]]|accessdate=September 25, 2015|deadurl=unfit|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925134424/http://www.wwe.com/inside/sting-interviewed-about-night-of-champions-injuries-27958909|archivedate=September 25, 2015}} ==== WWE Hall of Fame and retirement (2015–2016) ==== Sting said on the December 9 edition of [[Ric Flair]]'s ''WOOOOO! Nation'' podcast that he required surgery to correct [[cervical spinal stenosis]], and is "lucky that a [[Catastrophic injury|catastrophe]] didn't happen" in his match with Rollins at Night of Champions.{{cite web|url=http://www.f4wonline.com/daily-updates/daily-update-snukas-trial-date-set-sting-needs-neck-surgery-ufc-203331 |title=Snuka's trial date set, Sting needs neck surgery, UFC|date=December 9, 2015|website=Figure Four Weekly|publisher=[[Wayback Machine]]|accessdate=December 11, 2015 |deadurl=unfit|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151211092417/http://www.f4wonline.com/daily-updates/daily-update-snukas-trial-date-set-sting-needs-neck-surgery-ufc-203331|archivedate=December 11, 2015}} It was announced on the January 11, 2016 episode of ''Raw'' that Sting would be the first member of the [[WWE Hall of Fame]] Class of 2016. He was the second active WWE wrestler to be inducted – the first being his inductor, Ric Flair. Sting ultimately reneged on having surgery; on March 22, 2016 he explained that he felt "completely normal" and had none of the side effects associated with cervical spinal stenosis.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/article/sting-interview-retirement-exclusive?sf22959606=1|title=Exclusive interview: Sting on the Hall of Fame, his WWE experience and whether he has competed in his final match|last=Pappolla|first=Ryan|date=March 22, 2016|publisher=[[WWE]]|access-date=March 26, 2016}} On April 2, during his WWE Hall of Fame induction speech, Sting announced his retirement from professional wrestling. He appeared at [[WrestleMania 32]], alongside his fellow 2016 inductees, the following night.{{cite web|url=http://prowrestling.net/site/2016/04/03/powells-wrestlemania-32-live-review-undertaker-vs-shane-mcmahon-in-a-hell-in-a-cell-match-triple-h-vs-roman-reigns-for-the-wwe-championship-brock-lesnar-vs-dean-ambrose-in-a-street-fight-char/|title=Powell's WrestleMania 32 live review|last=Powell|first=Jason|date=April 3, 2016|publisher=ProWrestling.net|access-date=October 11, 2016}} In August 2016, Sting appeared on the [[WWE Network]] show ''Legends with [[John Layfield|JBL]]'' and talked about his career. He also stated that he has not undergone surgery, which would definitively end his career, and he still holds hope for a match with The Undertaker, claiming that such a match is his "unfinished business" in wrestling.{{cite web|url=http://411mania.com/wrestling/411s-legends-with-jbl-sting-report/|title=411's Legends with JBL: Sting Report|date=August 19, 2016|last=Leighty Jr.|first=Robert|work=411MANIA|accessdate=November 9, 2016}} == Legacy and influence == [[File:2016 Hall of Fame 2016-04-02 22-34-53 ILCE-6000 8461 DxO (27561151915).jpg|thumb|Sting's induction into the WWE Hall of Fame class of 2016]] Sting is widely regarded as the greatest performer in WCW history.{{cite book|last=Pantaleo|first=Steve|date=2015|title=WWE Ultimate Superstar Guide|publisher=[[Dorling Kindersley]]|page=177|isbn=978-1465431240}} Former rival [[Hulk Hogan]] asserted that Sting should be mentioned in any conversation regarding the top 10 greatest pro wrestlers of all time; numerous outlets have placed him in such listings.{{#tag:ref|See:{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/top-50-wrestlers-of-all-time?page=5 |title=Top 50 Wrestlers of All Time |date=November 2, 2012 |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=2015-05-21 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160923115236/http://www.ign.com/articles/top-50-wrestlers-of-all-time?page=5 |archivedate=September 23, 2016 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.insidestl.com/insideSTLcom/STLSports/STLMMAWrestling/tabid/256/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/6180/Top-50-Greatest-Professional-Wrestlers.aspx |title=Top 50 Greatest Professional Wrestlers |last=Mareno |first=Ace |date=February 18, 2011 |website=''[[WGNU|InsideSTL]]'' |publisher=[[CBS Sports Radio]] |access-date=June 23, 2015 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150623131205/http://www.insidestl.com/insideSTLcom/STLSports/STLMMAWrestling/tabid/256/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/6180/Top-50-Greatest-Professional-Wrestlers.aspx |archivedate=June 23, 2015 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.ebay.co.uk/gds/Top-10-Wrestlers-of-All-Time-/10000000205161756/g.html|title=Top 10 Wrestlers of All Time|date=April 30, 2015|publisher=[[eBay]]|access-date=November 7, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.watchmojo.com/video/id/11681/|title=Top 10 Wrestlers|last=Barnett|first=Ryan|publisher=[[WatchMojo.com|WatchMojo]]|access-date=June 21, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.smosh.com/smosh-pit/lists/20-greatest-wrestlers-all-time|title=20 Greatest Wrestlers of All Time|date=2010|publisher=[[Smosh]]|access-date=May 23, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://411mania.com/wrestling/ask-411-03-15-06-the-ultimate-dusty-finish-a-few-corrections-and-just-how-great-was-sting/|title=The Ultimate Dusty Finish, A Few Corrections, and Just How Great WAS Sting?|last=Napier|first=Gavin|date=March 15, 2006|publisher=411Mania|access-date=September 26, 2015|quote=I'd have a hard time putting [Sting] in the top five of all time, but he'd easily make my top ten.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150926151308/http://411mania.com/wrestling/ask-411-03-15-06-the-ultimate-dusty-finish-a-few-corrections-and-just-how-great-was-sting/|archivedate=September 26, 2015|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=https://www.si.com/extra-mustard/2016/07/26/wwe-wcw-ecw-100-best-wrestlers-all-time|title=Ranking the top 101 wrestlers of all time |last=Winkie|first=Luke|work=Sports Illustrated|date=July 26, 2016|accessdate=August 1, 2016}}|group=lower-alpha}} Sting also garnered one of the largest and most loyal fanbases in the industry; he was voted by ''[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated]]'' readers as "[[List of Pro Wrestling Illustrated awards#Most Popular Wrestler of the Year|Most Popular Wrestler of the Year]]" four times (a record shared with [[John Cena]]), for the years 1991, 1992, 1994 and 1997. [[Digital Spy]] writer Mayer Nissim commended Sting's ability to constantly evolve his [[Gimmick (professional wrestling)|gimmick]] while fellow [[franchise player]]s Hulk Hogan and John Cena largely failed to do so, in order to maintain spectator interest. Borden is known for his charity work,{{cite book|last=Hornbaker|first=Tim|date=2007|title=National Wrestling Alliance: The Untold Story of the Monopoly That Strangled Pro Wrestling|publisher=[[ECW Press]]|page=343|isbn=978-1550227413|quote=He is known for his charity work, and even if he were to never step into the ring again, his time as a wrestling hero will be remembered by the 'Little Stingers' who followed him every step of the way.}} once regarding his involvement with the [[Make-A-Wish Foundation|Make-A-Wish]] and [[Starlight Children's Foundation]]s as his "most fulfilling activity". His young supporters are known as the "Little Stingers". Prior to his signing with WWE, Sting's legacy was perpetuated by the organization. It hailed him as "one of sports-entertainment's elite",{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/superstars/sting |title=Sting (pre-debut) |website=Wayback Machine |publisher=WWE |access-date=May 3, 2012 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120503225407/http://www.wwe.com/superstars/sting |archivedate=May 3, 2012 }} and ranked him at number one in listings of the greatest wrestlers to never perform in WWE,[http://www.wwe.com/classics/classic-lists/10-greatest-never-in-wwe/page-11 The 10 Greatest Wrestlers to Never Wrestle in WWE]. WWE. June 5, 2013. Retrieved June 6, 2013. and the greatest stars in WCW history.[http://www.wwe.com/classics/wcw/50-greatest-wcw-stars/page-51 The 50 Greatest Stars in WCW History: Sting]. WWE. Retrieved May 24, 2012. In 2013, the company named Sting's WCW World Heavyweight Championship contest against [[Diamond Dallas Page]], on April 26, 1999, as the greatest match ever aired on WCW's flagship ''[[WCW Monday Nitro|Monday Nitro]]'' program.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/classics/classic-lists/20-greatest-wcw-matches/page-2|title=The 20 greatest WCW matches of all time|last=Powers|first=Kevin|date=January 22, 2013|publisher=WWE|accessdate=October 4, 2015}} At [[Night of Champions (2013)|Night of Champions 2013]], WWE organized a viewer poll to determine the greatest [[WWE United States Championship|United States Champion]] of all time: Sting, a two-time champion, beat out the other four contenders – all [[WWE Hall of Fame]]rs – in a [[landslide victory]] with 53% of the overall vote.[https://web.archive.org/web/20130919044446/http://www.wwe.com/shows/nightofchampions/2013/wwe-universe-votes-for-greatest-champions-26148649 The WWE Universe's picks for best champions ever]. WWE. September 15, 2013. Retrieved September 19, 2013. In regard to Sting's creative handling after he signed with WWE, ''PWInsider'' editor Dave Scherer wrote that "he really represented WCW so he was never going to get that [legend] treatment".{{cite web|url=http://www.pwinsider.com/article/108328/reading-vince-mcmahons-mind-aj-getting-into-the-title-match-miz-vs-cena-and-more.html?p=1|title=Reading Vince McMahon's mind, AJ getting into the title match, Miz vs. Cena and more|last=Scherer|first=Dave|date=March 15, 2017|website=PWInsider|access-date=March 18, 2017}} Sting was the inaugural inductee into the [[TNA Hall of Fame]]. TNA president Dixie Carter credits Sting with being the major wrestling superstar that TNA needed to establish itself.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/tna-news/33328-press-release-tna-makes-history-at-slammiversary|title=Press release: TNA makes history at Slammiversary|publisher=WrestleView|date=June 12, 2012|author=Martin, Adam}} The company describes him as having had an "unparalleled career" and as being a legend who surpasses time.{{cite web|url=http://www.impactwrestling.com/TNA-Alumni/item/1561-sting |title=Sting |publisher=TNA Wrestling |accessdate=January 5, 2015 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140421041811/http://www.impactwrestling.com/TNA-Alumni/item/1561-sting |archivedate=April 21, 2014 |df= }} Sting was regarded by colleagues in WCW as a professional and well-respected locker room leader.{{cite web|url=http://www.f4wonline.com/wwe-news/stings-light-wwe-dvd-boring-muted-experience-200611 |title=Sting's 'Into The Light' WWE DVD is a boring, muted experience |last=Cox |first=James |date=November 1, 2015 |website=Figure Four Weekly |publisher=[[Wayback Machine]] |access-date=November 7, 2015 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151107175547/http://www.f4wonline.com/wwe-news/stings-light-wwe-dvd-boring-muted-experience-200611 |archivedate=November 7, 2015 }} Prominent adversary [[Big Van Vader]] felt that Sting had unsurpassed athletic prowess within the business, and "ranks right up at the top" as an in-ring performer. [[Ric Flair]] called Sting his greatest opponent.{{cite web|url=http://www.pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/Torch_Flashbacks_19/article_84099.shtml|title=MNW Flashback|last=Powell|first=Jason|date=March 26, 2015|website=[[Wade Keller#Pro Wrestling Torch|Pro Wrestling Torch]]|access-date=March 31, 2017}} Former rival Diamond Dallas Page, commenting on Sting's entry into WWE in 2014, said: "Everyone there grew up watching him... No one did it better than Sting, nobody".{{cite web|url=http://www.alternativenation.net/jim-ross-ddp-lilian-garcia-preview-wwe-survivor-series |title=Jim Ross, DDP & Lilian Garcia Preview WWE Survivor Series |date=November 22, 2014 |website=Alternative Nation |publisher=[[Wayback Machine]] |access-date=November 25, 2014 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141125220944/http://www.alternativenation.net/jim-ross-ddp-lilian-garcia-preview-wwe-survivor-series |archivedate=November 25, 2014 }} [[John Cena]] mimicked Sting's hairstyle in his youth{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4Ga6d-jtEns&t=24s|title=A special look at Sting|date=February 23, 2015|publisher=WWE|access-date=May 22, 2015}} and recalled, "he was my guy";''Greatest Stars of the 90s''. [[WWE Home Video]]. 2009.
John Cena: "To see Sting win that match [vs. Ric Flair at The Great American Bash (1990)], obviously, as a kid I was going nuts: he was my guy."
Jeff Hardy: We went to see WCW in Fayetteville. There was this one moment, man, a changing moment in my life, when I reached out and I touched Sting... I was like, 'Wow, I wanna be that guy'." [[Cody Rhodes]]{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/classics/wcw/cody-rhodes-growing-up-wcw-26138473/page-4 |title=Growing up WCW |last1=Rhodes |first1=Cody |last2=Linder |first2=Zach |date=August 8, 2013 |publisher=[[WWE]] |access-date=July 18, 2015 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130811161126/http://www.wwe.com/classics/wcw/cody-rhodes-growing-up-wcw-26138473/page-4 |archivedate=August 11, 2013 |df= }} and [[Shelton Benjamin]]{{cite web|url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/2004/05/03/shelton-benjamin-interview?page=3|title=Shelton Benjamin Interview|last=Robinson|first=Jon|date=May 3, 2004|publisher=[[IGN]]|access-date=July 18, 2015}} have also named him as their favorite childhood wrestler. [[Tyson Kidd]] professed to being a "huge Sting fan" as a child, and [[Seth Rollins]] would dress up as Sting in his youth.{{cite web|url=http://www.pwinsider.com/article/97021/why-getting-in-the-ring-with-sting-was-unfathomable-could-we-be-looking-at-a-60-minute-seth-rollins-match-soon-more-wwe-world-heavyweight-champ-seth-rollins-on-pwinsidertv.html|title=WWE World Heavyweight Champ Seth Rollins on PWInsiderTV|last=Johnson|first=Mike|date=October 5, 2015|website=PWInsider|accessdate=October 6, 2015}} He was also a prominent influence on industry veterans [[Kurt Angle]],{{Cite episode|title=Kurt Angle pt 1|series=Vince Russo's The Brand|network=PodcastOne|date=April 22, 2016|quote=I learned a lot from Sting. He's the guy I wanted to be like.}} [[Bill Goldberg]],''Sting: Into the Light''. [[WWE Home Video]]. 2015.
Bill Goldberg: "I looked up to [Sting]."
Tyson Kidd: "I was a huge Sting fan as a kid." [[Jeff Hardy]],{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q_3gkiqEmfg&t=11s|title=Jeff Hardy on returning to WWE, his suspensions, the true 'best in the world', more|date=July 26, 2012|publisher=Chris Van Vliet|access-date=May 22, 2015}} [[Kane (wrestler)|Kane]],{{cite web|url=http://www.alternativenation.net/interview-kane-discusses-triple-h-sting-undertaker-daniel-bryan-see-no-evil-2/ |title=Kane Discusses Triple H, Sting, Undertaker, Daniel Bryan & See No Evil 2 |date=October 16, 2014 |publisher=Alternative Nation |access-date=October 31, 2015 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141018125206/http://www.alternativenation.net/interview-kane-discusses-triple-h-sting-undertaker-daniel-bryan-see-no-evil-2/ |archivedate=October 18, 2014 |df= }} [[A.J. Styles]] and [[Goldust]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/inside/sting-inside-the-ring-rivals-allies-27149066/page-3 |title=Goldust on Sting's influence |date=March 2, 2015 |publisher=[[WWE]] |access-date=November 7, 2015 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150304151003/http://www.wwe.com/inside/sting-inside-the-ring-rivals-allies-27149066/page-3 |archivedate=March 4, 2015 |df= }} [[Bray Wyatt]] has stressed that he "''really'' would like to take on" Sting, adding: "I have to have [that] before I die; I don't care if it happens outside a [[Waffle House]], somewhere."{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4G6n5Q9e038&t=14m33s|title=Bray Wyatt on Facing Undertaker at WWE WrestleMania 31, Getting Lost in Thoughts|date=March 28, 2015|publisher=Between The Ropes|access-date=July 26, 2015}} Sting was the only WCW World Heavyweight Champion to wear face paint.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/inside/sting-6-surprising-facts-wwe-wcw/page-3|title=6 surprising facts about Sting (page 3)|last=Artus|first=Matthew|date=September 13, 2015|publisher=WWE|access-date=November 7, 2015}} ===Drawing ability=== Sting's [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Draw|drawing]] ability has been disputed. Journalist Dave Scherer of ''PWInsider'' wrote: "Sting is an all timer for sure, but the fact is that when he was the man in WCW, even before the [[New World Order (professional wrestling)|NWO]] came in, he didn't draw huge".{{cite web|url=http://www.pwinsider.com/article/96981/what-i-dont-want-to-see-at-wrestlemania-32-stings-legacy-wwe-network-practices-and-more.html|title=What I don't want to see at WrestleMania 32, Sting's legacy, WWE Network practices and more|last=Scherer|first=Dave|date=October 3, 2015|website=PWInsider|accessdate=October 4, 2015}} Pro wrestling historian [[Dave Meltzer]] also reported that Sting was not a formidable draw.{{Cite episode|title=Steve Austin Pt 2|series=The Ross Report|network=PodcastOne|date=February 25, 2014|number=2|minutes=58}} Fin Martin of ''[[Power Slam]]'' felt that while Sting did not make "essential improvements" nor "grow into the champion's role" during his first NWA World Heavyweight Championship reign from 1990 to 1991, he suffered from a weak line-up of potential opponents and poor creative handling. Martin said that Sting never truly established himself as 'The Man'.{{cite web|url=http://www.powerslamonline.co.uk/updates/222/Raw-Shane-Sting-Hall-Of-Fame-.htm |title=The Mail |last=Martin |first=Fin |date=March 9, 2016 |website=[[Power Slam]] |publisher=[[Wayback Machine]] |access-date=March 10, 2016 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160311021516/http://www.powerslamonline.co.uk/updates/222/Raw-Shane-Sting-Hall-Of-Fame-.htm |archivedate=March 11, 2016 }} On the other hand, [[Stone Cold Steve Austin|Steve Austin]] has taken exception to the notion that Sting was not a profitable wrestler. Reflecting on Sting in the early 1990s, veteran wrestler [[Kevin Nash]] said: "There weren't many draws in WCW at that point, but he was one of them".{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2264924-kevin-nash-diamond-dallas-page-more-reminisce-on-stings-career-as-a-wcw-icon|title=Kevin Nash, Diamond Dallas Page, More Reminisce on Sting's Career as a WCW Icon|last=Greenberg|first= Keith Elliot|date=November 13, 2014|publisher=[[Bleacher Report|B/R]]|accessdate=March 11, 2016}} Former WCW [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Book|booker]] [[Mike Graham (wrestler)|Mike Graham]] asserted that Sting was a television ratings success during the [[Monday Night Wars]],{{cite AV media|people=Oliver, Sean (director)|year=2011|title=Guest Booker With Mike Graham|medium=DVD|publisher=Kayfabe Commentaries|quote=I had the TV people give me a minute-to-minute rating of all of our shows... when Sting was on TV, they watched.}} while fellow booker [[Kevin Sullivan (wrestler)|Kevin Sullivan]] said of Sting's rivalry with Ric Flair: "If I needed to draw a rating, Sting and Flair always drew. It was like [[Muhammad Ali|[Muhammad] Ali]] and [[Joe Frazier|[Joe] Frazier]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/ustv/s216/wwe/feature/a603155/8-things-we-learned-from-the-best-of-sting-dvd.html|title=8 things we learned from the Best of Sting DVD|last=Nissim|first=Mayer|date=October 13, 2014|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=January 15, 2015}} The [[Clash of the Champions#Clash of the Champions I|inaugural]] [[Clash of the Champions]] event in 1988, which aired opposite the WWF's [[WrestleMania IV]] and was headlined by Sting vs. Flair, generated a record-setting 5.6 rating on [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]].{{cite book|title=To Be the Man|author=[[Ric Flair]] & [[Keith Elliot Greenberg]]|date=2004|publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]]|isbn=978-1501123757|page=165}} The pair also main-evented [[The Great American Bash (1990)|The Great American Bash 1990]], which was the NWA's biggest [[pay-per-view]] success up to that point. Sting was a major attraction in 1997, being WCW's top merchandise seller (second only to the WWF's Steve Austin overall)Molinaro, John F. ''The Top 100 Pro Wrestlers of All Time'' (''[[Dave Meltzer#Wrestling Observer Newsletter|Wrestling Observer]]''). Winding Stair Press. 2002. Page 197. {{ISBN|1553663055}}. and, versus [[Hulk Hogan|Hollywood Hogan]], headlining the biggest-grossing pay-per-view event in the company's history at [[Starrcade (1997)|Starrcade 1997]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/The_Specialists_34/article_24141.shtml|title=Nostalgia: Starrcade '97|last=Hoops|first=Brian|date=January 7, 2008|publisher=PWTorch|access-date=June 21, 2015}} Sting went on to join the [[New World Order (professional wrestling)|nWo Wolfpac]] [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Stable|stable]], which dominated WCW's merchandise sales at events in mid 1998.{{cite web|url=http://www.f4wonline.com/news/june-22-1998-wrestling-observer-newsletter-wcw-great-american-bash-review-details-karl |title=WCW Great American Bash review, details on Karl Malone/WCW, tons more |date=June 22, 1998 |website=Wrestling Observer Newsletter |access-date=March 9, 2016 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160309095041/http://www.f4wonline.com/news/june-22-1998-wrestling-observer-newsletter-wcw-great-american-bash-review-details-karl |archivedate=March 9, 2016 }} Discussing Sting in WWE, Kevin Nash said that he is "so valuable to the company as a trademark". === Resistance to signing with WWE === Prior to his signing with WWE, Sting was widely considered the greatest wrestler never to perform for the company.{{cite web|url=http://www.techtimes.com/articles/10493/20140715/wrestling-legend-sting-will-pre-order-bonus-wwe-2k15.htm|title=Wrestling legend Sting will be a pre-order bonus in 'WWE 2K15'|last=Serafino|first=Jason|date=July 15, 2014|website=Tech Times|access-date=July 21, 2015}} He had "really good conversations" with the promotion during his career,{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/ustv/s216/wwe/news/a586447/sting-on-wwe-match-i-promise-you-it-will-be-showtime.html#~pdVe29uNxawu2t|title=Sting teases showtime at WWE match|date=July 25, 2014|publisher=}} but did not appear there until 2014, at the age of 55. His loyalty to WCW, even in its dying days, has been noted. That organization was purchased by the WWF (now WWE) in 2001, and Sting's contract with its parent company [[Time Warner|AOL Time Warner]] expired in 2002, but he still refused to make the jump, alternately attributing this to the WWF's creative usage of former WCW talents and negative dealings with attorneys.{{cite web|url=http://grantland.com/the-triangle/wwe-survivor-series-sting-john-cena-the-authority-vince-mcmahon-wwe-network-triple-h-dean-ambrose-bray-wyatt-wcw-monday-night-wars/|title=WWE 'Survivor Series': Sting! WTF?|first=David|last=Shoemaker|date=November 25, 2014|publisher=}} The company's onerous live schedule and the content of its programming were also factors. Sting has, however, downplayed rumors of a difficult relationship with WWE. Rather than sign with the WWF in 2002, Sting performed for smaller promotions, becoming the centerpiece of TNA by the mid 2000s. His pre-WWE career included "dream" matches against former WWF stars [[Hulk Hogan]] and [[Bret Hart]] in WCW,{{cite web|url=http://www.pwinsider.com/article/70713/looking-at-sting-vs-hogan-the-dream-match-that-wouldnt-go-away.html|title=Looking at Sting vs Hogan: the dream match that wouldn't go away|last=Carapola|first=Stuart|date=August 1, 2012|website=PWInsider|access-date=July 22, 2015}}{{cite journal|last=Holmes|first=Colin|date=October 30, 2014|title=The Best of Sting|journal=[[Fighting Spirit Magazine]]|publisher=Uncooked Media|issue=112|pages=68|quote=[T]he set ends with two dream matches, as Sting teams with The Ultimate Warrior to face Bret Hart and Hollywood Hogan, before battling "The Hitman" in singles action.}} as well as bouts opposite names such as [[Ric Flair]], [[Randy Savage]], [[Kurt Angle]] and [[Mick Foley]]. Sting often wrestled Steve Austin in WCW; he had positive negotiations with WWE in 2003, with his proposed debut [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Angle|angle]] being a confrontation with Austin at the conclusion of [[WrestleMania XIX]].{{cite web|url=http://uproxx.com/prowrestling/2015/06/sting-almost-wrestled-stone-cold-steve-austin-at-wrestlemania-19/|title=Sting Almost Wrestled Stone Cold Steve Austin At WrestleMania 19|last=Stroud|first=Brandon|date=June 2, 2015|publisher=[[Uproxx]]|access-date=July 22, 2015}} He was also "very, very close" to making a deal with the company in 2011, which would potentially have involved a match against [[The Undertaker]] at [[WrestleMania XXVII]].{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.com/Slam/Wrestling/2012/06/08/19852511.html|title=Ever evolving Sting ready for Roode, TNA title at Slammiversary|author=Bishop, Matt|work=[[Canoe.ca]]|publisher=[[Quebecor Media]]|date=June 8, 2012|accessdate=July 22, 2015}} Although Sting twice wrestled Mark Calaway in his pre-Undertaker character, Mark Callous, at WCW live events in 1990,{{cite web|url=http://411mania.com/wrestling/ask-411-wrestling-has-sting-v-undertaker-happened-already/|title=Has Sting V Undertaker Happened Already?|last=Sforcina|first=Mathew|date=December 10, 2014|website=411Mania|access-date=December 11, 2015}} WWE viewers clamored for a televised Sting versus Undertaker match.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/anthonydimoro/2015/10/26/wwe-is-building-to-sting-undertaker-wrestlemania-dream-match/2/|title=WWE Is Building To Sting & Undertaker WrestleMania Dream Match (page 2)|last=DiMoro|first=Anthony|date=October 26, 2015|website=[[Forbes]]|access-date=November 11, 2015}} == Other media == Borden appeared in the music video for the song "Fire in the Hole" by [[Lȧȧz Rockit]] in 1989. Borden appeared in the syndicated TV show [[Super Force]] as Hallor / ... (3 episodes, 1991-1992) He starred in a pay-per-view only film titled ''The Real Reason (Men Commit Crimes)'' (1998). Borden was featured in a [[Sprite (soft drink)|Sprite]] commercial in 1999. He also appeared in three episodes of the action-adventure series with [[Hulk Hogan]] in ''[[Thunder in Paradise]]'' as the character Adam "Hammerhead" McCall.{{cite web|url=http://fly.hiwaay.net/~djberry/tv/thunder.htm |title=Thunder in Paradise Episode Guide |publisher=Fly.hiwaay.net |date= |accessdate=2012-12-10}} Borden made a guest appearance on ''[[Walker, Texas Ranger]]'' as biker and drug dealer Grangus in the episode "Unsafe Speed". He also appeared in ''Ready to Rumble'' (2000) as Sting. His book, Moment Of Truth, was released on December 1, 2004. He also appeared in the Christian film, ''[[The Encounter (2010 film)|The Encounter]]'' (2010) and was featured as the lead actor in the TV movie ''Shutterspeed'' (2000). He makes a cameo appearance as Sting on an episode of ''Upright Citizens Brigade''. Borden played an outlaw biker in the film ''Revelation Road'' (2013). In October 2015, WWE released a second Sting DVD titled ''Sting: Into the Light''. The three-disc set features a behind-the-scenes documentary with Sting himself as he prepares to step into a WWE ring for the first time ever at WrestleMania 31. == Personal life == Borden was an admitted [[anabolic steroid]] user in the 1980s.{{cite web|url=http://www.muscleandfitness.com/athletes-celebrities/news/wcw-and-tna-wrestler-sting-speaks|title=WCW and TNA Wrestler Sting Speaks|last=Tuthill|first=Matt|website=[[Muscle & Fitness]]|publisher=[[American Media (publisher)|American Media, Inc.]]|access-date=July 5, 2015}} He became a [[born again (Christianity)|born-again Christian]] in August 1998, after confessing his [[adultery]], and [[Substance abuse|substance]] and [[alcohol abuse]] to his then-wife. Borden has two sons, Garrett Lee and Steve, Jr. and a daughter named Gracie, who was born in 2000.{{cite web |url=https://www.cbn.com/700club/guests/interviews/steve_borden_111504.aspx |title=Sting' Out of the Ring |accessdate=2010-11-26 |publisher=CBN.com |date=November 15, 2004}} His elder son Garrett attends [[Azusa Pacific University]], where he plays college football as a running back.{{cite web |url=http://www.apu.edu/athletics/football/bios/bordengarrett/ |title=No. 38 – Garrett Borden |accessdate=2010-11-25 |publisher=APU.edu |date=November 25, 2010}} Steven attended [[Kilgore College]], where he played tight end; on December 19, 2012, he committed to attend the [[University of Kentucky]].{{cite web |url=http://www.kilgore.edu/Football/Mugs450x680_2012/450x680/steven-borden_450x680.JPG |title=No. 7 – Steven Borden |accessdate=2012-09-14 |publisher=kilgore.edu |date=September 14, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201170831/http://www.kilgore.edu/Football/Mugs450x680_2012/450x680/steven-borden_450x680.JPG |archivedate=February 1, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} After the [[2015 NFL Draft]], Steven was invited by the [[Kansas City Chiefs]] to try out for the team at their rookie mini-camp.{{cite web|title=Chiefs invite interesting class of rookies to 3-day minicamp|url=http://hosted2.ap.org/GALAG/3b2e65c0a10e42c9a9b81ff30a6a9a35/Article_2015-05-16-FBN--Chiefs%20Minicamp/id-9c0c70dd7a554005a4cc1d00bc857f8b|website=LaGrangenews.com}} Borden married his second wife Sabine in 2015, shortly after WrestleMania 31. == Championships and accomplishments == {{multiple image |direction = vertical |width = 200 |image1 = StingNWAChampionship2006.png |caption1 = A two-time [[NWA World Heavyweight Championship|NWA World Heavyweight Champion]], Sting had one reign each in WCW and TNA. |image2 = StingTNAChampionship.png |caption2 = Sting's total of four reigns {{Italic title}} [[File:მარიამისეული ქართლის ცხოვრება.JPG|thumb|270px|''The Georgian Chronicles'', [[Mariam Dadiani|Queen Mariam]]'s version.]] [[File:ანასეული ნუსხა.jpg|thumb|270px|''The Georgian Chronicles'', [[Alexander I of Kakheti#Family|Queen Ana]]'s version.]] The '''''Georgian Chronicles''''' is a conventional [[English language|English]] name for the principal compendium of medieval [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] historical texts, natively known as '''''Kartlis Tskhovreba''''' ({{lang-ka|ქართლის ცხოვრება}}), literally "Life of Kartli", [[Kartli]] being a core region of ancient and medieval Georgia, known to the [[Classical antiquity|Classical]] and [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] authors as [[Caucasian Iberia|Iberia]].
The chronicles are also known as '''''The Georgian Royal Annals''''', for they were essentially the official corpus of history of the [[Kingdom of Georgia]].<ref name="Rapp">Rapp, Stephen H. (2003), ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=nCFwaxMumWkC Studies in Medieval Georgian Historiography: Early Texts And Eurasian Contexts]'', ''passim''. Peeters Publishers, {{ISBN|90-429-1318-5}}. Retrieved on 26 April 2009.</ref><ref name="Toumanoff ">[[Cyril Toumanoff|Toumanoff, Cyril]] (1963). ''Studies in Christian Caucasian History''. Washington, D.C.: [[Georgetown University Press]], ''passim''.</ref>
== Chronicles == The Chronicles consist of a series of distinct texts dating from the 9th to the 14th century. The dating of these works as well as the identification of their authors (e.g., [[Leonti Mroveli]] and [[Juansheriani]]) have been a subject of scholarly debates. Although many scholars in Georgia still propose an 11th-century dating for the first redaction of the corpus, the increasing number of modern experts has accepted Professor [[Cyril Toumanoff]]'s hypothesis that the earliest texts of ''Kartlis Tskhovreba'' were composed c. 800. The latest texts were added in the 14th century. A "canonized" version was edited by a special commission appointed and chaired by King [[Vakhtang VI of Kartli]] early in the 18th century.<ref name="Rapp"/>
During the 11th century, the first three works – the "History of the Kings and Patriarchs of the Georgians", the "History of King Vakhtang Gorgasali", and the "Martyrdom of Saint Archil" – already made up a first corpus which covered the Georgian history from the earliest times through the reign of [[Vakhtang I Gorgasali]] (r. 452–502/22) down to the death of Vakhtang's descendant [[Archil of Kakheti|Archil]] (786). In the middle of the 12th century, two texts were added: the "Chronicle of Kartli" – which records the Georgian history from the late 8th century through the reign of the first all-Georgian king [[Bagrat III of Georgia|Bagrat III]] (r. 1008-1014) to the early regnal years of [[George II of Georgia|George II]] (r. 1072-1089) – and the "History of the King of Kings David" – which continues the story and focuses on the reign of [[David IV of Georgia|David IV]] (r. 1089-1125).<ref name="Rapp"/>
== Manuscripts ==
The extant Georgian manuscripts of ''Kartlis Tskhovreba'' are relatively late, with the earliest, the so-called ''Anaseuli'' or "[[Alexander I of Kakheti#Family|Queen Anna]]" codex, dating from the period of 1479-1495. Another major variant, ''Mariamiseuli'' or "[[Mariam Dadiani|Queen Mariam]]" codex, was copied in the years 1633-1645/1646. However, the surviving Georgian manuscripts are predated by the Chronicles' abridged [[Armenian language|Armenian]] adaptation known as "The History of Georgians" (''Patmut'iwn Vrats'''), most probably made in the 12th century, with its earliest extant manuscript being copied in the period of 1279-1311.<ref name="Rapp"/>
A number of translations are available in French, Russian, English and German, but each one covers only a selected number of these texts.
== Authenticity ==
Some modern scholars, such as [[Ivane Javakhishvili]], have questioned the authenticity of the early components of "The Georgian Chronicles" and have called for extreme caution when working with them. Indeed, strict historical facts are frequently intermingled with mythical ones, making it sometimes difficult to discern true historiography and mythology. However, critical analyses against other sources, including the [[Classical antiquity|Classical]] authors, and a series of recent archaeological studies have proved the trustworthiness of many of the Chronicles' accounts. These texts relate evidence not only for the history of Georgia, but also [[Armenia]] and the [[Caucasus]] in general, [[Iran]], [[Syria]], [[Anatolia]], the [[Roman Empire]], the [[Khazars]], and the [[Turkish people|Turks]].<ref name="Rapp"/>
== Components ==
{| class="wikitable" |- ! English name ! Georgian name ! Transliteration ! Date ! Author ! Period covered |- | History of the Kings and Patriarchs of the Georgians | ცხოვრება ქართუელთა მეფეთა და პირველთაგანთა მამათა და ნათესავთა | ''tskhovreba kartuelta mepeta da pirveltaganta mamata da natesavta'' | 9th or 11th century |[[Leonti Mroveli]] (?) |4th century BC – 5th century AD |- | History and life of King [[Vakhtang Gorgasali]] | ცხოვრება და მოქალაქეობა ვახტანგ გორგასლისა | ''tskhovreba da mokalakeoba vakhtang gorgaslisa'' | c. 800 or 11th century |[[Juansher Juansheriani]] |5th–8th centuries |- | Martyrdom of Holy and Magnificent [[Archil of Kakheti|Archil]] | წამება წმიდისა და დიდებულისა არჩილისი | ''tsameba tsmidisa da didebulisa archilisi'' |9th or 11th century |Juansheriani or Mroveli |736–786 |- |Chronicle of Kartli |მატიანე ქართლისა |''matiane kartlisa'' |11th century |Anonymous |786–1072 |- |History of the King of Kings [[David IV of Georgia|David]] |ცხოვრება მეფეთ მეფისა დავითისი |''tskhovreba mepet mepisa davitisi'' |12th century |Anonymous |1072–1125 |- |History of the [[Bagrationi|Bagratids]] |ცხოვრება და უწყება ბაგრატონიანთა |''tskhovreba da utsqeba bagratonianta'' |11th century |[[Sumbat Davitis-Dze]] |6th century–1031 |- |Histories and Eulogies of the Sovereigns |ისტორიანი და აზმანი შარავანდედთანი |''istoriani da azmani sharavandedtani'' |13th century |Anonymous |1156-1212 |- |History of the Five Reigns |ლაშა-გიორგის დროინდელი მატიანე |''lasha-giorgis droindeli matiane'' |1223 |Historian of [[George IV of Georgia|George IV]] |1125-1223 |- |History of the King of Kings [[Tamar of Georgia|Tamar]] |ცხოვრება მეფეთ მეფისა თამარისი |''tskhovreba mepet mepisa tamarisi'' |13th century |Anonymous |1184–1210/1213 |- |Chronicle of a Hundred Years |ასწლოვანი მატიანე |''astslovani matiane'' |14th century |Anonymous |1212-1318 |}
